Using toluene catalytic combustion as a probe reaction, simulating quantitative sulfur poisoning by in situ thermal decomposition of ammonium sulfate solution, the study used MgO modified γ-Al2O3 to support cobalt-based catalyst, and the result displayed that the catalyst exhibited excellent sulfur poisoning resistance. The successful construction of MgO-Al2O3 heterogeneous interface weakened the interaction between Co and Al and reduced the production of inactive CoAl2O4. Besides that, it fixed sulfur species and formed MgSO4 to protect active components. The dual function of MgO have been proved by various characterization experiments. The modification of γ-Al2O3 by the appropriate amount of MgO could improve the catalytic activity of Co/γ-Al2O3. Meanwhile, T 100 increased from 300 °C to 330 °C after 1.6 wt% sulfur poisoning and we concluded that the decrease in catalytic performance was not caused by the loss of active Co, but by the decrease of specific surface area and lattice oxygen activity. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Sulfur-tolerance mechanism Catalytic combustion Structure-activity relationship MgO modified γ-Al2O3 Cobalt-based catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Atmospheric pollutants are mainly composed of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), causing both environmental pollution and health diseases [1,2]. The emission reduction of industrial VOCs still depends on terminal treatment technology in the process of industrial structure transformation, in which technology of catalytic combustion has been widely used, and the key core of this technology is to obtain efficient catalysts [3–6]. During catalytic combustion, supported transition metal catalyst is a common choice. As a typical spinel phase transition metal oxide, Co3O4 has attracted extensive attention, and it is considered a substitute for precious metal catalysts in the catalytic combustion of VOCs [7–9]. Because of its coordination structure and changeable valence, Co3O4 has excellent catalytic performance. And trivalent cobalt ion is the main active site of catalytic oxidation, while divalent cobalt ion has low activity [10,11]. But when carriers were used to support Co3O4 to disperse cobalt and increase the specific surface area, strong interaction between cobalt and carriers will inevitably occur. Specifically, when the carrier is γ-Al2O3, this cobalt-carrier interaction usually caused Co3+ ions to be partially reduced to Co2+ and then fixed in the lattice of alumina, which led to the formation of cobalt aluminate (CoAl2O4) [12]. The formation of inactive CoAl2O4 inevitably led to the decline of catalytic performance. Therefore, it was necessary to design a modified carrier to reduce the interaction between Co and Al. Zhao et al. [13] added MgO to modify the carrier γ-Al2O3-TiO2. They found that Mg-Al spinel was produced after MgO was added, which could fully disperse Co3O4 and improve the catalytic efficiency of propane. In a word, the addition of MgO reduced the interaction between Co and Al in the catalyst and avoided the loss of active cobalt species. Efficient catalysts should not only show high catalytic activity, but also show good stability and durability in harsh reaction environment [14–16]. The effect of MgO changes the strong interaction between Co and Al, and also makes the catalyst have certain sulfur resistance. As mentioned at the beginning, in the process of catalytic combustion, the catalyst will inevitably encounter complicated and harmful environment. In the atmosphere containing trace sulfur species, catalyst poisoning is serious. However, there are few studies on the method and mechanism of sulfur poisoning. Laboratories usually adopt various means to simulate sulfur poisoning. The first was direct catalytic combustion of Sulfur-containing VOCs (SVOCs) in the air atmosphere by Kucherov et al. [17]. The second was to pulse SO2 gas during the catalytic combustion of VOCs by Alifanti et al. [18] and Flouty et al. [19]. These methods were slow to simulate the process of catalyst poisoning, and it cannot accurately quantify the degree of catalyst poisoning. Therefore, the in-situ thermal decomposition method of ammonium sulfate was used to simulate sulfur poisoning rapidly and quantitatively [20–22]. As for the mechanism of sulfur poisoning, taking our previous work as an example, no matter transition metals such as Mn [20], Co [21], or precious metal Pd [22], in the presence of sulfur species, they will be deactivated because the active components will combine with sulfur species to generate sulfate. Thereby reducing the number of active components and the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Many researchers will choose to add MgO to improve the sulfur resistance of the catalyst. Yang et al. [23] added MgO and γ-Al2O3 carrier to form MgAl2O4 spinel. It can compete with Pd-Pt active component for SOx adsorption, further protecting Pd-Pt active component from sulfur species. The development of high catalytic toluene performance and sulfur poisoning resistance cobalt-based catalyst by adding alkaline MgO to modify the carrier γ-Al2O3 was highly desirable. In the paper, γ-Al2O3 was modified with MgO by precipitation method, and then Co/Mg-γ-Al2O3 was prepared by equal volume impregnation method. Solution of (NH4)2SO4 was used to simulate sulfur poisoning quantitatively by the thermal decomposition method. The catalysts before and after poisoning were characterized, the effects of adding MgO on the sulfur resistance of the catalyst tested and analyzed, and the reasons that affected the catalytic combustion of toluene discussed. 2 Experiment 2.1 Preparation of catalyst MgO-modified γ-Al2O3 was synthesized by precipitation method. γ-Al2O3 (99.9 %, 40–60 mesh) was put into a flask, mixed with Mg (NO3)2·6H2O solution. Then, a solution of 1.2 M Na2CO3 was added dropwise while the temperature of the mixture was kept at 80 °C, until the pH was 8.5. The obtained precipitates were dried under ultraviolet lamp and roasted at 500 °C for 2 h to get XMg-γ-Al2O3 (X stands for the magnesium loading: 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10, 15 and 20 wt%). Co/XMg-γ-Al2O3 of 10 wt% Co was prepared by equal volume wet impregnation method [21]. 2.2 Process of sulfur poisoning Thermal decomposition of ammonium sulfate solution was used to poison the catalyst sulfur rapidly and quantitatively [20]. The thermal decomposition of ammonium sulfate solution with different concentrations was used to simulate different sulfur poisoning degrees. The catalysts for different sulfur poisoning were named as Co/XMg-γ-Al2O3-YS (Y stands for the sulfur loading: 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 0.8 and 1.6 wt%). 2.3 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance was evaluated by WFS 3010 microreactor (Xianquan, Tianjin, China). In the reaction, air with a toluene concentration of 1000 ppm was introduced, at a velocity of 20,000 h−1. The concentration of toluene was determined by hydrogen flame ionization detector and online gas chromatograph (GC-14 C, Shimadzu, Japan). The reaction temperature was kept at 200 °C. All gases in effluent were detected, the turnover frequency of toluene (TOF, defined as mol of C7H8 converted/mol of Co atom per second) was calculated based on toluene conversion. 2.4 Characterization Crystal structure of catalysts was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction with Cu Kα radiation, 40 kV, 40 mA, 0.02°/s (PANalytical, Almelo, Netherlands). The structure and groups of the catalyst were determined by Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FT-IR, Nicole Company, USA). Weight loss of catalysts was tested on a Thermogravimetry Analyzer (TG, Mettler-Toledo, Switzerland). Cobalt ions, aluminum ions and magnesium ions in the supernatant of the catalyst dissolved in water were detected by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP, Prodigy XP, USA). Specific surface area and pore volume was tested by Tristar II 3020 (BET, Micromeritics, USA). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEM-2010, Japan) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, OXFORD INCA, UK) were used to determine the surface morphology and element distribution of the catalysts. The elemental and valence analysis were tested by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi, USA), Al Kα (1486.6 eV) light source and C1s standard (284.8 eV). 2.5 Temperature programmed test H2-programmed temperature reduction (H2-TPR) was performed by CHEMBET-3000 (Quanta Chrome, USA). NH3-programmed temperature desorption (NH3-TPD) and toluene-programmed temperature desorption (Toluene-TPD) were tested online by Gas Mass Spectrometer (MS, QGA, Hidden, HK). For Toluene-TPD, 1000 ppm toluene was injected into the reaction system, and nitrogen (50 mL/min) was used as carrier gas for purging. Using a heating rate of 10 °C/min, the desorption experiment was carried out by heating to 500 °C. 2.6 In-situ infrared test In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments were carried out on a Nicolet 6700 FT-IR equipped with a nitrogen-cooled mercury-cadmium-telluride detector (MCT). About 50 mg of catalyst was pre-treated by heating for 2 h at 400 °C in argon (30 mL/min) to remove the adsorbed CO2 and H2O, and then cooled to 50 °C. Then the argon feeding stream containing 1000 ppm toluene flowed through the catalyst for 30 min to get a saturated adsorption. Subsequently, the samples were heated up to 100, 150, 200, 250, 300 and 350 °C respectively, and the spectrum was recorded. 3 Results 3.1 Structural and physicochemical properties analysis Fig. 1 showed the XRD of all catalysts. Fig. 1a revealed that, upon increasing the MgO addition, the diffraction peaks broadening and the intensity decreasing occurred for all the peaks: 31.1º, 36.8º, 44.7º, 59.2º, and 65.1º, corresponding to Co3O4 or CoAl2O4 (JCPDS No. 042-1467 and JCPDS No. 010-0458) [24]. With the increase of MgO addition, the interaction between cobalt and aluminum was weakened, and the signal of 36.8º for Co/γ-Al2O3 shifted towards a low angle, being this diffraction angle virtually coincident with that observed when cobalt was supported on pure magnesia (Co/MgO). This shows that the cobalt phase switched from a Co-Al-type interaction to a Mg-Al-type interaction [25]. Meanwhile, the diffraction peaks of MgO (43.0º and 62.4º, JCPDS No. 045-0946) were only found in Co/20Mg-γ-Al2O3. Fig. 1b illustrated that, as the degree of sulfur poisoning increased, the diffraction peaks of the catalysts did not change obviously and γ-Al2O3 (37.3º, 46.2º, 67.2º, JCPDS No. 049-0134) modified by magnesium showed stability. The crystal phase structure of the catalyst was not changed by sulfur poisoning. Because of its low sulfate content or amorphous structure, no diffraction peak was found in the spectrum. Raman spectra of the catalysts were given in Fig. 2. Five Raman bands at around 191.7 cm−1, 477.9 cm−1, 524.2 cm−1, 615.8 cm−1, and 685.4 cm−1 were observed, respectively corresponding to the F1 2g, Eg, F2 2g, F3 2g, and A1g modes of the Co3O4 spinel structure [26]. MgO-containing catalysts showed relatively weak and broad signals. The diffraction peak at 701 cm−1 attributed to CoAl2O4 disappeared [12]. Compared with Co/γ-Al2O3, the addition of MgO made the A1 g band have obvious red shift (the specific deviation degree can be seen in Fig. S2), which indicated that the lattice distortion of the cobalt phase had occurred. In line with the XRD results, it showed the interaction between Co3O4 and γ-Al2O3 to form inactive CoAl2O4 was weakened after the addition of MgO. And the existence of MgO led to lattice distortion, resulting in some defect sites [27]. Additionally, for Co/5Mg-γ-Al2O3-1.6 S, the blue shift and reduction of the A1g band at 690.6 cm−1 was caused by sulfur poisoning, indicating sulfate was produced by sulfur poisoning [28]. The infrared spectra of samples were shown in Fig. 3a, and there were six obvious absorption peaks of Co/5Mg-γ-Al2O3. The obvious peaks at 3440 cm−1 and 1640 cm−1 were corresponding to O–H stretching vibration from H2O and γ-Al2O3 [29,30], and peaks at 1494 cm−1 and 1390 cm−1 were caused by the stretching vibration of Mg-O [31]. The absorption band at 574 cm−1 was attributed to Co–O stretching vibration [32]. When the catalyst was affected by sulfur poisoning, a new absorption peak corresponding to SO4 2- appeared at 1113 cm−1 [33]. As the sulfur poisoning of catalyst deepened, the characteristic peak of sulfate was obviously enhanced, while the peak of Mg–O decreased. It can be inferred that MgSO4 was produced by the reaction of MgO and sulfur species on sulfur poisoning catalysts. MgSO4 can be found in thermogravimetric analysis. TG curve of the catalysts in N2 atmosphere was shown in Fig. 3b, indicating at 840 °C there was an obvious weight loss of MgSO4 for Co/5Mg-γ-Al2O3-1.6 S [34]. This was because when sulfur poisoning reached a certain level, it overflowed to the surface of Mg-γ-Al2O3. MgO was an alkaline oxide, which was easy to react with acidic sulfur species, resulting in MgSO4 accumulation on the catalysts. Thus, its decomposition can be seen at the corresponding temperature. Because sulfate was easily soluble in water, the poisoned catalyst was washed several times with deionized water to obtain supernatant. As shown in Table S1, the content of Co, Al and Mg in the supernatant were measured by ICP. For the catalysts without MgO, sulfur species were reacted with Co3O4 or Al2O3. For those with MgO, the result showed that MgO played a role in absorbing sulfur species and protecting the active component cobalt in the catalyst. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of fresh and poisoned catalysts were shown in Fig. 4, and pore structure parameters were listed in Table 1. Obviously, all of the samples exhibited type IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loop at P/P0 = 0.6–1.0 in Fig. 4a, indicating the presence of mesoporous structure in all the catalysts [35]. This was confirmed by the appearance of uniform mesopores of 9.3 nm in Fig. 4b. The S BET decreased after adding MgO modification and sulfur poisoning, meaning that the generated sulfate covered part of the pore structure and reduced S BET . Meanwhile, as the degree of sulfur poisoning increased, the V p continued to decrease, but the average pore diameter did not change significantly. This indicated that sulfur poisoning only blocked the pores by producing sulfate. As we all know, the decrease of S BET and V p means that the adsorption capacity of toluene is reduced. It was one of the reasons for the decline of catalytic activity. The results of toluene-TPD were showed in Fig. S1. It showed the desorption temperature of toluene shifted to low temperature after sulfur poisoning, which illustrated that the process of sulfur poisoning would weaken the adsorption strength between Co/5Mg-γ-Al2O3 and toluene. The ability to adsorb and activate toluene was weakened to some extent, which made the catalytic combustion performance decline. The images of the samples were explored via the HRTEM, as shown in Fig. 5. A rod-shaped γ-Al2O3 structure modified by MgO was shown in Fig. 5a. According to the EDS mapping images in Fig. S3, it can be found that MgO was uniformly loaded on the surface of γ-Al2O3. The morphology of Co/5Mg-γ-Al2O3 was shown in Fig. 5b. By zooming part of the image, we could observe the excellent crystallinity of cobalt species with obvious lattice stripe distribution. Compared with Fig. 5c and Fig. 5d, it can be found that the diameter of Co3O4 particles was larger due to sulfur poisoning. It was speculated that the sulfur species affected the overall environment of the catalyst surface, and the newly generated sulfate partially gathered around Co3O4. The two regions of Co/5Mg-γ-Al2O3-1.6S were analyzed by EDS spectrum in Fig. 5e and Fig. 5f. From the map, it can be found that the distribution of S element in the carrier (Region 2) was significantly better than that of Co3O4 (Region 1), which further showed that γ-Al2O3 modified by MgO can adsorb sulfur species more easily, thus protecting the Co3O4. This made the catalyst have a certain ability to resist sulfur poisoning. At the same time, it also showed that MgSO4, produced after sulfur poisoning, gathered around the Co3O4 and covered part of the active sites. 3.2 XPS analysis The samples were tested by XPS, and the effects of MgO and sulfur poisoning on the valence state and composition of elements were analyzed. XPS spectra of Co and S were shown in Fig. 6. In Fig. 6a, the binding energy at ∼780.7 eV and ∼795.8 eV of the peaks were corresponding to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 signals, respectively [10]. By fitting the XPS data, each characteristic peak was fitted to obtain two peaks, which corresponded to the surface Co3+ and Co2+ species. And the ratio had not changed significantly with the deepening of poisoning, indicating the valence state of cobalt species had not changed in this process. At the same time, in Fig. 6b, there were two peaks at ∼168.3 eV and ∼169.5 eV for sulfur poisoning samples, corresponding to SO4 2- 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively [36]. The characteristic peak of sulfate increased with the increase of sulfur species introduced, indicating that sulfate was formed and accumulated on the catalyst surface. This corresponded to the results of ICP, which fully showed that active cobalt (Co3+) had not been affected by sulfur species and had a valence transformation. 3.3 Temperature programmed experiment The redox performance of the catalysts before and after poisoning was tested by H2-TPR. The fresh catalyst displayed two H2 consumption peaks in Fig. 7. The peak at 425 °C was the reduction one of Co3O4, while that of Co-Al and Mg-Al interaction were at 722 °C [12]. With the addition of sulfur species, it was obvious that the reduction temperature of Co3O4 gradually increased from 425 °C to 455 °C. This was because the generated sulfate gathered around the cobalt species, covering part of the cobalt and reducing its redox ability. However, there was no significant change in the content of active cobalt species in Table 2, suggesting that the active cobalt species did not react with the sulfur species, which was consistent with the XPS analysis above. Then, it was noted that there was a reduction peak at 681 °C after the introduction of sulfur species [37]. Along with the deepening of sulfur poisoning, area of reduction peak increased, and the position of reduction peak moved to lower temperature. Because of the presence of MgO, generated MgSO4 accumulated on the catalyst. Moreover, with the sulfur poisoning reaching a certain level, the decomposition peak of MgSO4 had become two, which was caused by hydrogen overflow [22]. The acid sites of the catalyst were tested by NH3-TPD. Acid sites of the catalyst can be attributed to weak (<250 °C), medium-strong (250–400 °C), and strong acid sites (>400 °C). In Fig. 8, there were two distinct NH3 desorption peaks for each catalyst. The acid sites of Co/5Mg-γ-Al2O3 were derived from the Co3O4 and γ-Al2O3. The strong acid of the catalysts was conducive to activating the toluene adsorbed on the catalysts and thus promoted the catalytic combustion process of toluene [38]. It can be found that the desorption peak of 400 °C increased as the influence of sulfur poisoning deepened and moved to higher temperature, which indicated that the site of strong acid was increasing. This was because MgO, an alkaline substance in the catalyst, was continuously consumed into MgSO4, which then enhanced acidity directly. 3.4 Performance test of catalytic toluene and test of stability The catalytic activity of Co/γ-Al2O3 modified with different MgO content were shown in Fig. 9a. It was not difficult to find that the modified carrier containing MgO did not obviously improve the catalytic activity of toluene. The best performance was from the catalysts with MgO modification at 5 wt% and T 100 was decreased by 20 °C from 330 °C to 310 °C. This conclusion has also been proven through TOF testing (Table S2). This was because MgO weakened the interaction between Co3O4 and Al2O3, thus reduced the generation of inactive CoAl2O4 [12], indirectly increased the content of active cobalt species and improved performance. However, when the addition of MgO increased, the S BET and V p of Co/γ-Al2O3 were greatly reduced, therefore the adsorption capacity of toluene was reduced, leading to degradation of catalytic performance. The catalytic activity of Co/5Mg-γ-Al2O3 before and after sulfur poisoning were displayed in Fig. 9b. With the intervention of sulfur species, the catalytic activity of Co/5Mg-γ-Al2O3 declined, but the decline was not significant, from 310 °C to 340 °C. There were two main reasons for the decline in activity. On one hand, the decrease of S BET and V p, due to the partially blocked pore by MgSO4 as indicated by N2 adsorption-desorption and toluene-TPD, led to a decrease in activity with the weakening ability to adsorb toluene. On the other hand, although Co3+ was not lost, the generated MgSO4 covered some of the active components and weakened the redox ability of the catalysts. The process of catalytic combustion by transition metal oxides followed the MVK mechanism and lattice oxygen played a vital role. The influence of lattice oxygen before and after sulfur poisoning in the system was studied by in-situ DRIFT technology. Fig. 10 showed the FT-IR spectra of the samples at different temperatures with 1000 ppm toluene in argon atmosphere. There were characteristic peaks of intermediate products before and after catalyst poisoning. With the increase of temperature, the intermediate products were continuously transformed, and the characteristic peaks were continuously weakened. For the fresh catalyst in Fig. 10a, the characteristic peaks of main intermediate products were at 1601 cm−1, 1560 cm−1 and 1425 cm−1, which corresponded to the characteristic peaks of bidentate carbonate species [39]. For the poisoned catalyst in Fig. 10b, the characteristic peak of the intermediate products was at 1352 cm−1, which corresponded to the characteristic peak of enol species [40]. At the same temperature, the intermediate products changed before and after sulfur poisoning of catalysts, and it was mainly caused by the change of lattice oxygen activity [41]. In the process of sulfur poisoning, MgO in the system could capture sulfur species and form MgSO4. However, with the aggregation of MgSO4, the lattice oxygen was affected, and the activity decreased, resulting in decrease of catalytic performance despite that there was no loss of active components. To study whether the influence of sulfur poisoning on the activity will change in the long-term reaction, the durability of the catalyst before and after poisoning was tested for 100 h (Fig. S4). The results showed that the activity of the catalyst had not changed significantly after 100 h of reaction at T90. This proved that the catalytic performance of the catalyst itself was very stable and the sulfur poisoning of the catalyst was irreversible. Sulfate species formed on the catalyst by sulfur poisoning cannot be removed even after a long time of reaction. 4 Discussion The in-situ thermal decomposition of ammonium sulfate solution was used to simulate the different sulfur poisoning degrees of the catalyst. A series of studies were carried out on the catalysts of sulfur poisoned in various degrees, and the reaction mechanism of sulfur poisoning was clarified by various characterization. For catalyst Co3O4/γ-Al2O3, the corresponding poisoning mechanism has been studied in the previous work. The main reason for the decline in the catalytic performance of toluene by sulfur poisoning is that the active Co3+ in Co3O4 becomes CoSO4 under the condition of sulfur poisoning. In this paper, MgO, an alkaline substance, was tried to modify the carrier γ-Al2O3 to make it easier to adsorb acidic sulfur species, which can be regarded as a sacrificial agent in the process of sulfur poisoning. In addition, the addition of MgO blocked the Al-Co interaction and reduced the formation of inactive CoAl2O4. All experimental data supported the above conclusion. MgO successfully attracted sulfur species and formed MgSO4. Although there was no loss of Co3O4 in this process, the performance of catalytic combustion of toluene was still reduced. This is because the catalytic combustion mechanism of transition metal oxides mostly follows the MVK mechanism, in which the most critical one is the role of lattice oxygen in the whole process. In this study, the in-situ infrared measurement of toluene catalytic combustion on the catalyst before and after poisoning showed that the intermediate products changed obviously before and after poisoning, which indicated the change of lattice oxygen activity. After sulfur poisoning, the lattice oxygen activity became worse, thus reduced the catalytic performance. The decrease of lattice oxygen activity was from the changes of the micro-environment of the catalyst surface due to the formation of MgSO4. 5 Conclusion The poisoned catalysts were obtained by in situ thermal decomposition of ammonium sulfate solution. Compared with the fresh Co/5Mg-γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the toluene conversion temperature of 1.6 wt% sulfur poisoned catalyst was increased only by 30 °C. MgO, as a carrier modifier, not only weakened the interaction between Co and Al and improved the catalyst activity, but also fixed sulfur species and protected active components. In addition, the good sulfur resistance of the catalyst was mainly due to the existence of the MgO-Al2O3 heterogeneous interface. The reason for the decline of catalytic performance was not the loss of active cobalt species, but the pore blockage and decrease of lattice oxygen activity caused by magnesium sulfate. The study provided a new idea for the preparation of cobalt-based sulfur-tolerant catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Using toluene catalytic combustion as a probe reaction, simulating quantitative sulfur poisoning by in situ thermal decomposition of ammonium sulfate solution, the study used MgO modified γ-Al2O3 to support cobalt-based catalyst, and the result displayed that the catalyst exhibited excellent sulfur poisoning resistance. The successful construction of MgO-Al2O3 heterogeneous interface weakened the interaction between Co and Al and reduced the production of inactive CoAl2O4. Besides that, it fixed sulfur species and formed MgSO4 to protect active components. The dual function of MgO have been proved by various characterization experiments. The modification of γ-Al2O3 by the appropriate amount of MgO could improve the catalytic activity of Co/γ-Al2O3. Meanwhile, T 100 increased from 300 °C to 330 °C after 1.6 wt% sulfur poisoning and we concluded that the decrease in catalytic performance was not caused by the loss of active Co, but by the decrease of specific surface area and lattice oxygen activity.
coredata.dc:title: Sulfur-tolerant mechanism in catalytic combustion of toluene over Co/5Mg-γ-Al2O3 catalyst: Dual functions of MgO
